Fax: +86 27 87543632 (P. Liu), +31 40 2455054 (E.J.M. Hensen). Graphical abstract Achieving high yields in the production of bulk chemicals is an important goal for the chemical industry. We investigated the influence of the metal on the catalytic performance of M/MgCuCr2O4 (M=Cu, Ag, Pd, Pt, Au) catalysts to better understand the metal–support synergy for the aerobic oxidation of ethanol. Pt/MgCuCr2O4 and Pd/MgCuCr2O4 are more active and less selective for ethanol oxidation than the other catalysts, mainly because they can dehydrogenate and then cleave the carbon–carbon bonds in ethanol at relatively low temperature. Because of the facile oxidation of Cu0 and Ag0 under aerobic oxidation conditions, Cu/MgCuCr2O4 and Ag/MgCuCr2O4 are less active for ethanol oxidation. On contrary, Au/MgCuCr2O4 is a very active, selective and stable catalyst for sustainable production of acetaldehyde, achieving 96% selectivity at full ethanol conversion (space–time–yield up to 583galdehyde gAu −1 h−1) at 250°C. Low gold loading and high gold dispersion are important to enhance the Au0–Cu+ synergy and the catalytic efficiency of Au/MgCuCr2O4. Keywords Gold Platinum Copper Spinel support Selective oxidation Ethanol Acetaldehyde Synergy 1 Introduction Producing bulk chemicals from renewable biomass instead of depleting fossil resources is of great importance to sustainable goals of the chemical industry [1,2]. As a result, ethanol production from biomass fermentation has become increasingly competitive. Currently, 90% of the ethanol on the market has been obtained from biomass with an annual bioethanol production over 100billionliters [3]. Ethanol can be used as a fuel, but it is also very promising as a platform molecule for the production of value-added chemicals [4]. For instance, ethanol can be used as a renewable feedstock for the production of acetaldehyde (AC), acetic acid and ethyl acetate through selective oxidation or dehydrogenation. In particular, AC is a versatile bulk chemical with a worldwide production over 106 tons/year. It is currently mainly produced by the oxidation of fossil ethylene in a homogeneous catalytic system containing of HCl, PdCl2 and CuCl2 (the Wacker process) [5]. Here, a promising opportunity arises to replace petroleum-based ethylene by renewable ethanol for more green and sustainable acetaldehyde production. Recently, interest has been growing in the application of supported metal catalysts in gas-phase partial oxidation of ethanol [6]. Many efforts have been focused on the use of platinum group [7–10] and IB group [11–24] metals. Among these catalysts, supported gold nanoparticles (AuNP) are the most promising for aerobic ethanol oxidation [16–24] mainly due to the high AC selectivity and the good stability against metal oxidation that otherwise will deactivate the catalyst. The catalytic performance of supported AuNP catalysts for aerobic ethanol oxidation was demonstrated to be superior to non-oxidative ethanol dehydrogenation [17,22,24]. The catalytic performance depends on the AuNP size [16,17,23] and the acid–base or redox properties of the support [6,18,22]. It has also been reported that supported bimetallic Au–Cu [25,26] and Au–Ir [27] catalysts show synergy in the aerobic oxidation of ethanol. However, a drawback of these catalysts is that the higher temperature required for higher ethanol conversion usually results in lower AC selectivity and poor stability. These aspects limit practical application of supported metal catalysts for the selective oxidation of biobased ethanol. In aerobic oxidation with Au NPs, metal–support interactions are usually found to be beneficial for the catalytic performance [28,29]. It is thought that the support facilitates the activation of molecular oxygen and the alcohol group because of the low affinity of gold with these reactants [30–32]. Although reducible TiO2 can activate O2 at modest temperature, its surface acidity makes Au/TiO2 catalyst less selective for aerobic ethanol oxidation [19–21,24]. Solid base supports facilitate ethanol dehydrogenation; despite the high AC selectivity, ethanol conversion is, however, usually limited [18,22]. Recently, we have reported that Au/MgCuCr2O4 is an excellent catalyst for gas-phase ethanol oxidation to AC (space–time–yield, STY ∼311galdehyde gAu −1 h−1 at 250°C with over 95% AC yield; no catalyst deactivation) [33]. It was shown that surface Cu cations maintain the 1+ oxidation state and work in synergy with AuNPs. At the interface, O2 can be efficiently activated. DFT calculations demonstrated that Cu ions in the surface of the MgCr2O4 spinel decrease the oxygen vacancy formation energy [32]. The reduced Cu surface site and basic oxygen atom (O atoms of the support as well as adsorbed O2 − species) at the interface of Au/MgCuCr2O4 are responsible for O2 activation and O–H bond activation of ethanol, respectively. Here, we expand the scope of the MgCuCr2O4 spinel by exploring its potential as a support for nanoparticles of various transition metals (M=Cu, Ag, Pd, Pt and Au) for aerobic ethanol oxidation. Although more reactive metals than gold yield more active catalysts, selectivity is typically impeded by C–C bond cleavage reactions. The results firmly demonstrate that Au is the best choice when high selectivity and yield of acetaldehyde are desired. We also explore in more detail the effect of gold loading and AuNP size to optimize the Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O), chromium nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), silver nitrate (AgNO3), tetraammine palladium(II) nitrate solution (Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, 10wt% in H2O), tetraammine platinum(II) nitrate (Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2), gold(III) chloride trihydrate (HAuCl4·3H2O) and ethanol (absolute, >99.8%) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Mg0.75Cu0.25Cr2O4 spinel (denoted as MgCuCr2O4) was prepared by a coprecipitation–calcination method [33]. Typically, a mixed nitrate solution with stoichiometric amount of Mg(NO3)2/Cu(NO3)2/Cr(NO3)3 =3/1/8 was adjusted to pH∼11.0 by dropwise addition of 1M NaOH solution to ensure full precipitation. The precipitate was filtered, washed and dried at 110°C overnight, and then the solid was further calcined at 650°C in air for 8h to yield the spinel support. M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts (M=Cu, Ag, Pd, Pt) were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation method, using Cu(NO3)2, AgNO3, Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 as metal source with expected 1.0, 1.0, 0.5 and 0.5wt% metal loading, respectively. After impregnation, the samples were dried at 110°C and then calcined at 300°C in air for 5h. The catalysts were finally reduced in H2 at 300°C for 5h. Four Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts were prepared by homogeneous deposition–precipitation of HAuCl4 using urea as the precipitation agent [34] with expected 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0wt% Au loading, respectively. The catalysts were finally calcined in air at 350°C for 5h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an Empyrean with Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 30mA). The BET surface area was recorded on a Tristar 3000 automated gas adsorption system. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired on a FEI Tecnai G2 20 electron microscope at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. The average metal particle size was calculated by counting ∼200 metal particles. The metal loadings of the M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts were determined by a Perkin Elmer AA-300 atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurements were performed using a Thermo VG Multilab 2000 spectrometer. The spectra were recorded by using an aluminum anode (Al Kα radiation at 1486.6eV). Energy corrections were performed by using C 1s (284.5eV) as a reference. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements Ethanol oxidation experiments were carried out in a fixed bed plug flow reactor system [33]. Typically, 0.1g of catalyst diluted with 0.3g of α-Al2O3 was loaded into a stainless steel reactor with an internal diameter of 6mm. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was treated with a mixture 10vol.% H2 in N2 at 300°C for 2h. The reactant feed mixture was obtained by evaporating ethanol in a He stream in a controlled evaporator mixers (Bronkhorst). The volumetric composition of the feed mixture was ethanol/O2/He=1/3/63. The total gas flow rate was 167mL/min with ethanol flow rate ∼2.5mL/min (1.5vol.%) and the GHSV was 100,000mLgcat −1 h−1 for all experiments. The reaction products were analyzed online by using GC (Interscience GC-8000) equipped with a 30m Rtx-Wax capillary column and a Shincarbon ST80/100 packed column. In all cases, the carbon balances closed at 100±2%. The occurrence of internal and external mass and heat transfer limitations was tested by the established Maers and Thiele modulus criteria (see the Supporting Information). The results of this analysis show that, at complete conversion at 250°C, the reported rate is nearly completely controlled by chemical kinetics. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of M/MgCuCr2O4 The MgCuCr2O4 support had the same structure as MgCr2O4 spinel (JCPDS 10-0351) as confirmed by XRD analysis. All M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts were reduced at 300°C in H2 before characterization. No apparent diffraction peaks of metal were observed (Fig. 1 ), indicating that all metals were present as well dispersed nanoparticles on the MgCuCr2O4 support. The metal loading procedure did not change the textural properties of the support (S BET =12m2/g; Vp =0.04cm3/g). Data about the metal loading and average metal particle size are collected in Table 1 . The metal loadings are close to the targeted values (1.0wt% for Cu and Ag, 0.5wt% for Pd, Pt and Au). As shown in Fig. 2 , TEM analysis of M/MgCuCr2O4 revealed that the metal phase was present as highly dispersed clusters with mean cluster size around 1.0nm for Cu and Ag and around 1.2nm for Pd and Pt. The mean particle size of Au was larger (2.5nm). The oxidation state of the supported metal particles was studied by XPS. The fresh calcined MgCuCr2O4 spinel support was used as a reference for comparison to reduced M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts. The Cu 2p3/2 XP spectra (Fig. 3 A) show that the lower binding energy (BE) peak at ∼932eV increased significantly after metal loading and reduction. This finding points to an increase of surface Cu+ or Cu0 species upon reduction [35]. Because Cu 2p3/2 XPS cannot differentiate between Cu+ and Cu0, Auger Cu LMM spectra were used to confirm the presence of Cu+ at BE ∼570eV (Fig. 3B). The surface Cu+ fraction derived from Cu LMM spectra increased from 20% for MgCuCr2O4 to 57% for Au/MgCuCr2O4 (Table 1). Basically, these surface Cu+/Cu atomic ratios are consistent with the values derived from Cu 2p3/2 XP spectra, except for Cu/MgCuCr2O4, indicating the selective reduction of surface Cu2+ to Cu+ in the MgCuCr2O4 support. The higher Cu+ fraction by Cu 2p3/2 for Cu/MgCuCr2O4 is due to the presence of Cu0, originating from the reduction of the copper nitrate-derived CuO phase. The finding that the reduced catalysts contain an increased fraction of reduced Cu+ ions is in agreement with our previous results [33,36]. Most of the other catalysts also contain the transition metal nanoparticles in reduced form. The Ag 3d XP spectra (Fig. 3C) show a single Ag 3d5/2 peak at 368.3eV, which can be assigned to Ag0 [37]. For Pd/MgCuCr2O4 (Fig. 3D), the catalyst contains both Pd0 and Pd2+. Despite the signal overlap with the MgCuCr2O4 support, the Pd 3d5/2 peak could be deconvoluted into two contributions at 335.8 and 337.9eV assigned, respectively, to Pd0 and Pd2+ [38]. The occurrence of Pd2+ species in the reduced catalyst is probably due to the facile oxidation of small Pd0 clusters in air. The severe overlap of the Pt 4f signal with the support (Fig. 3E) does not allow for a meaningful deconvolution of the Pt 4f peaks. The Au 4f7/2 peak was located at 83.9eV, the typical value for metallic Au0. 3.2 Catalytic performance of M/MgCuCr2O4 Firstly, we investigated the effect of different metals on the catalytic performance of M/MgCuCr2O4 in gas-phase aerobic oxidation of ethanol (Table 1). All M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts were pretreated at 300°C in H2 before reaction. As compared with the bare MgCuCr2O4 spinel, reduced M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts exhibited improved ethanol conversion at 200°C, especially in the case of Pd, Pt and Au. Pt/MgCuCr2O4 showed the highest activity with ethanol conversion up to 92%, however, at a relatively low AC selectivity of 30%. Similarly, Pd/MgCuCr2O4 showed higher activity (56%) but lower AC selectivity (72%) than Au/MgCuCr2O4 (39% and 99%, respectively). In contrast, Cu/MgCuCr2O4 and Ag/MgCuCr2O4 showed the same high AC selectivity (99%), but much lower ethanol conversion as compared with Au/MgCuCr2O4. For better comparison, Fig. 4 shows the temperature dependence of ethanol conversion and product selectivity over various catalysts. The MgCuCr2O4 spinel showed much lower activity than M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts, obtaining only 25% of conversion and 98% of AC selectivity at 275°C. At the same temperature, Cu/MgCuCr2O4 and Ag/MgCuCr2O4 had ethanol conversion values of 65% and 60% with 88% and 95% of AC selectivity, respectively. The other three M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts completely converted ethanol. For Pd/MgCuCr2O4 and Pt/MgCuCr2O4, in addition to CO2, four more by-products were obtained, i.e., ethyl acetate, ethylene, acetic acid and methane. These products were already observed at temperatures below 150°C. The formation of methane is consistent with the high activity of Pd and Pt toward C–C bond cleavage reactions. Such reactions are absent for the gold catalyst. Interestingly, Pt/MgCuCr2O4 achieved 31% of conversion at 100°C with 85% of AC selectivity and a STY of 165gAC gPt −1 h−1. However, with the temperature increasing to 200°C, the AC selectivity decreased dramatically to 30% and CO2 selectivity increased to 57%. As a result, the highest AC yield was only 36% obtained by Pt/MgCuCr2O4 at 175°C with a highest STY of 226gAC gPt −1 h−1 (Fig. 5 ). For MgCuCr2O4-supported Pd, Cu, Ag catalysts, the maximum AC yield and STY were obtained at 225°C (58%, 380gAC gPd −1 h−1), 275°C (57%, 187gAC gCu −1 h−1), and 300°C (73%, 242gAC gAg −1 h−1), respectively. In contrast, Au/MgCuCr2O4 achieved 91% of AC yield and 583gAC gAu −1 h−1 of STY at 250°C. Thus, the gold catalysts outperformed all of the other catalysts. The overall activity for the M/MgCuCr2O4 increases in the order Pt>Pd>Au>Ag>Cu; from the viewpoint of selective AC production, the preferred catalyst is Au followed by Pd, Ag, Pt and Cu. 3.3 Comparison against state-of-the-art catalysts To compare the metal–support synergy of the M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts, their AC selectivity and STY values were compared with state-of-the-art supported metal catalysts (Table 2 ). Interestingly, all M/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts show higher AC selectivity and STY than the reference catalysts. For the less active Cu/MgCuCr2O4, the STY (187h−1 at 275°C) is higher than Cu/RHA (125h−1 at 275°C, RHA=rice husk ash), which was previously reported as the most efficient catalyst for the non-oxidative ethanol dehydrogenation to AC [6,11]. Ag/MgCuCr2O4 (65h−1 at 225°C) is more efficient than nanoporous silver (21h−1 at 250°C) [15] and Ag-hollandite (26h−1 at 230°C) [13] for aerobic ethanol oxidation. Similarly, Pd/MgCuCr2O4 (61h−1 at 150°C) and Pt/MgCuCr2O4 (165h−1 at 100°C) are superior to Pd/Al2O3 (8h−1 at 160°C) [7] and Pt/ZrO2 (127h−1 at 300°C) [9], respectively. Au/MgCuCr2O4 (250h−1 at 200°C) outperforms Au/SiO2 (30h−1 at 200°C) [16], Au/MoO3 (27h−1 at 240°C) [18], Au/TiO2 (3h−1 at 200°C) [19], Au/Recryst-S1 (135h−1 at 200°C) [23] and AuCu/SiO2 (14h−1 at 200°C) [25]. These comparisons suggest the presence of strong synergistic effect between the metal nanoparticles and the MgCuCr2O4 support in aerobic ethanol oxidation, presumably due to the abundant surface Cu+ species and basic oxygen species in MgCuCr2O4 for facile activation of O2 and alcohol group [32,33]. XPS results of spent catalysts (Fig. 6 ) showed that the surface Cu2+ fraction (derived from Cu 2p3/2) of Cu/MgCuCr2O4 increased from 56% to 62%, while the Ag 3d5/2 peak of Ag/MgCuCr2O4 shifted from 368.3 to 367.8eV. These data point to facile oxidation of Cu0 to Cu2+ and Ag0 to Ag+ under the aerobic oxidation conditions. Similarly, metallic Pd and Pt are expected to partially oxidize during the oxidative reaction [39], although this cannot be confirmed by XPS due to the peak overlap. In contrast, the Au 4f7/2 and Cu 2p3/2 peaks of Au/MgCuCr2O4 are almost unchanged in the Au0 and Cu+/Cu≈56% state after ethanol oxidation. It is worthwhile to briefly discuss the performance differences among the various transition metals. Pt and Pd are more reactive than gold and, accordingly, they will display increased rates of oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol. However, the increased C–H bond breaking activity also results in further dehydrogenation of acetaldehyde. The resulting surface fragments are the precursor to C–C bond cleavage. After C–C bond cleavage, the products are CH4 and CO2 at low temperature, and mainly CO2 at higher temperatures. The α-C–H bond breaking of ethanol will be suppressed on the partially oxidized Ag and Cu surfaces. Due to the low Au–O binding energy, Au is not the preferred catalyst for the activation of O2 and the O–H and C–C bonds of ethanol [32]. The difficulty to split the C–C bond is important to attain high AC selectivity at elevated temperatures. For Au, the specific role of Cu+ is the activation of O2, which acts as a basic site for the O–H bond cleavage in ethanol. This explains why the synergy with the Cu-containing spinel support is optimal for Au. It provides a more selective and efficient route for ethanol oxidation to AC than the alternative use of platinum and IB group metals. As a result of the different Au loading, the present Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst shows a much higher STY (583h−1 at 250°C) than our previously reported one (311h−1 at 250°C) [33]. Accordingly, we investigate in more detail the effect of Au loading in the next section. 3.4 Effect of gold loading of Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst The Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst was further optimized by varying the gold loading (Table 3 ). With increasing gold loading from 0.46wt% to 1.76wt%, the mean gold particle size increased from 2.5nm to 4.3nm (Fig. 7 ). As a result, ethanol conversion at 200°C decreased from 73% (Au/MgCuCr2O4-II, 2.9nm) to 56% (Au/MgCuCr2O4-IV, 4.3nm), despite the difference in gold loading. The corresponding quasi turnover frequency (qTOF) values based on the AC yield and gold dispersion decreased with increasing AuNP size from 2363h−1 (2.9nm) to 2110h−1 (3.2nm) and 1374h−1 (4.3nm). We stress that these qTOF values represent lower boundary estimates of the real TOF because of the high conversion. For Au/MgCuCr2O4-I (2.5nm), moderate activity (qTOF∼2128h−1) was obtained. At 200°C, the activity order was II>I∼III>IV. When the reaction temperature was increased to 250°C, the order changed to I>II>III∼IV. The ethanol conversion of Au/MgCuCr2O4-I substantially increased to 95% with 96% of AC selectivity, achieving a qTOF as high as 5028h−1, which is twice the value of Au/MgCuCr2O4-III and IV. These results indicate that the optimum catalytic performance occurs at different temperatures for the various Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts. Fig. 8 shows the temperature dependence of ethanol conversion, AC selectivity, AC yield and qTOF over various Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts. Au/MgCuCr2O4-III obtained 98% of conversion and 98% of AC selectivity at 225°C, thus achieving the highest AC yield (96%) among the four catalysts. The other three catalysts reached their maximum yield at 250°C, with 91%, 95% and 94% for Au/MgCuCr2O4-I, II and IV, respectively. High AC selectivity (>90%) and yield were maintained at 275°C, resulting in relatively stable qTOF values for various Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts in a certain temperature region. Significantly, the qTOF values of Au/MgCuCr2O4-I are much higher than those of the other catalysts above 200°C, primarily due to its lower gold loading and higher gold dispersion. The relevance of the Au0–Cu+ synergy to explain the improved performance is supported by the surface Cu+/Au atomic ratios derived from XPS (Table 3). Au/MgCuCr2O4-I contains more Cu+ sites per Au atom than the other three catalysts. As expected on the basis of the Au–Cu+ synergy [32], this ratio correlates with the catalytic performance. Based on these results, it is reasonable to conclude that increasing the gold loading leads to lower gold dispersion and lower catalytic activity of Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst. Thus, it appears that Au/MgCuCr2O4-I (0.46wt% Au) is the optimum catalyst for ethanol oxidation. The most important corollary of these findings is that increased gold dispersion leads to increased Au0–Cu+ interactions which benefits the catalytic performance of Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst for sustainable AC production from ethanol. 3.5 Stability of the optimal Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst In an attempt to evaluate the stability of Au/MgCuCr2O4-I, continuous ethanol oxidation was performed for prolonged times. The catalytic activity did not change significantly after the first 100h on-stream (Fig. 9 ), with ethanol conversion and AC selectivity at 250°C slightly decreasing from 95% to 92% and from 96% to 95%, respectively. It should be pointed out that this observation is different from our previous report [33], in which ethanol conversion increased from 95% to 100% after running at 275°C for 50h. As discussed previously, the increased catalytic performance was mainly due to the increased surface Cu+ species and enhanced Au0–Cu+ synergy during long-term reaction. Catalyst pretreatment in H2 at 300°C will also increase the Cu+ concentration. In this study, we pretreated the catalysts in H2 at 300°C to increase the surface Cu+ fraction from 20% to 57% (see Table 1 and Fig. 3) before the reaction was started. This pretreatment is expected to maintain stable Au0–Cu+ synergy during ethanol oxidation. XPS results proved the presence of a nearly unchanged surface Cu+ fraction (56%, derived from Cu 2p3/2 spectra, Fig. 6F) in the spent catalyst after 120h on-stream. This is consistent with the observation that the ethanol conversion was almost the same before and after running the reaction at elevated temperatures in the present study. TEM (Fig. 7d) shows a slight increase in mean AuNP size for the spent Au/MgCuCr2O4-I catalyst from 2.5nm to 2.8nm, which explains the slightly higher surface Cu+/Au atomic ratio (see Table 3). N2 physisorption results show that the textural properties of the spent Au/MgCuCr2O4-I catalyst (S BET =12m2/g; Vp =0.036 cm3/g) did not appreciably change during the ethanol oxidation reaction at 300°C for 50h. Thus, we argue that the small decrease in ethanol conversion is mainly due to gold sintering during reaction at high temperature. The qTOF based on surface gold atom, however, increased slightly (see Table 3). As discussed previously, the MgCuCr2O4 spinel stabilizes AuNP in the sense that the loss of dispersion is very small over long reaction times [33]. The strong interaction between AuNP and MgCuCr2O4 support bears resemblance to the Au–support interactions in Au/CeO2 [40]. The excellent catalytic stability is consistent with our proposal that the catalytic site is located at the perimeter of the AuNP and the support, comprising Au0 and Cu+. The present results provide insights into the nature of metal–support synergy for aerobic ethanol oxidation. 4 Conclusions We have shown that the metal–support synergy strongly affects the catalytic performance of MgCuCr2O4 spinel-supported platinum and IB group metals for gas-phase ethanol oxidation. MgCuCr2O4 supported Pt and Pd catalysts exhibit higher activity but lower acetaldehyde selectivity than the supported Cu, Ag and Au catalysts. This is mainly due to the higher reactivity of Pd and Pt that leads to C–C bond scission reactions and gives rise to complete oxidation. Ag/MgCuCr2O4 and Cu/MgCuCr2O4 show much lower activity than Au/MgCuCr2O4, because Ag and Cu are more prone to oxidation than Au. The stable and specific Au0–Cu+ synergy renders Au/MgCuCr2O4 the most efficient and selective catalyst for sustainable production of acetaldehyde from ethanol, achieving a space–time–yield up to 583galdehyde gAu −1 h−1 at 250°C. We have demonstrated that the catalytic performance strongly depends on the synergy between Au0 and Cu+ sites at the nanoparticle/support perimeter. Acknowledgments Dr. P. coredata.dc:description: Achieving high yields in the production of bulk chemicals is an important goal for the chemical industry. We investigated the influence of the metal on the catalytic performance of M/MgCuCr2O4 (M=Cu, Ag, Pd, Pt, Au) catalysts to better understand the metal–support synergy for the aerobic oxidation of ethanol. Pt/MgCuCr2O4 and Pd/MgCuCr2O4 are more active and less selective for ethanol oxidation than the other catalysts, mainly because they can dehydrogenate and then cleave the carbon–carbon bonds in ethanol at relatively low temperature. Because of the facile oxidation of Cu0 and Ag0 under aerobic oxidation conditions, Cu/MgCuCr2O4 and Ag/MgCuCr2O4 are less active for ethanol oxidation. On contrary, Au/MgCuCr2O4 is a very active, selective and stable catalyst for sustainable production of acetaldehyde, achieving 96% selectivity at full ethanol conversion (space–time–yield up to 583galdehyde gAu −1 h−1) at 250°C. Low gold loading and high gold dispersion are important to enhance the Au0–Cu+ synergy and the catalytic efficiency of Au/MgCuCr2O4.
coredata.dc:title: On the metal–support synergy for selective gas-phase ethanol oxidation over MgCuCr2O4 supported metal nanoparticle catalysts
